importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei made a prediction in March 2025 about AI writing 90% of code within three to six months.
Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg made a prediction in April 2025 about AI contributing to half of software development in one project within the next year.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article discusses AI's potential to revolutionize software engineering between 2025 and 2026, with predictions from tech CEOs about significant code generation by AI within the next year or two.

keyTakeAways: Tech CEOs such as Dario Amodei (Anthropic), Mark Zuckerberg (Meta), Amazon, Google, and Microsoft claim AI is already writing a large portion of code, with some predicting up to 90% AI-written code in the near term.

Despite enthusiastic claims, many software engineers remain skeptical, noting that AI-generated code often requires extensive review and correction, and that AI frequently fails or produces 'messy blobs' of non-functional code.
AI tools are most effective for short-term, repetitive, or low-accuracy tasks (e.g., prototyping), but struggle with higher-level problem-solving, which is central to engineering.
Studies show mixed results: a METR study found LLMs increased task completion time by 19% among experienced engineers, while a Danish survey found only modest time savings (6.5%) with AI.

Concerns include overuse of AI without justification (called 'workslop'), lack of human oversight, potential job displacement of junior software engineers, and environmental costs from training large AI models.
AI tools are not fully autonomous — even advanced agents like Anthropic's Claude Code still require human review and final approval for every line of code.
Engineers report that while AI improves efficiency for specific tasks, it is not a substitute for human judgment, creativity, and system-level problem-solving.

Some companies, like Amazon and Meta, have pushed aggressive AI adoption, even leading to firings for not using AI tools sufficiently, indicating cultural pressure to adopt AI regardless of practical need.

namedEntities.name: Dario Amodei
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He predicted that AI would write 90% of code within three to six months, setting a major tone for AI's role in software development.

namedEntities.name: Mark Zuckerberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He predicted that AI would contribute to half of a project's development within the next year, signaling confidence in AI’s impact on software engineering.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is highlighted for its AI tool use policies, employee pressure to adopt AI, and a case where an engineer described how AI misuse created unworkable code.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google is mentioned in relation to a survey showing only half of engineers 'somewhat' trust AI responses, indicating skepticism among developers.

namedEntities.name: Microsoft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Microsoft is cited as one of the tech companies that has highlighted large language models' code generation capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Anthropic
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Anthropic developed Claude Code, an AI tool capable of generating and testing code, and is discussed in relation to its agents and human review requirements.

namedEntities.name: Claude Code
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Claude Code is presented as a key example of AI agents that can auto-test and rewrite code, though it still requires human oversight and review.

namedEntities.name: Simon Willison
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He evaluates AI's role in coding, noting that AI cannot replace human problem-solving and that productivity gains are task-specific and limited.

namedEntities.name: Colton Voege
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a personal example of a software engineer who tried AI tools and found limited long-term efficiency gains, and who is now considering starting a new business due to changing tech priorities.

namedEntities.name: Y Combinator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Y Combinator supported Voege's startup and previously promoted AI as a 'productivity booster,' showing a shift in investment focus toward AI alone.

namedEntities.name: METR
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: METR conducted a study showing that experienced open-source engineers using LLMs took 19% longer to complete tasks, contradicting AI hype.

namedEntities.name: Anders Humlum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Co-author of Danish study on AI use
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided data from a Danish survey showing AI led to only modest time savings (6.5%), highlighting skepticism about AI's productivity claims.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Tech CEOs such as Dario Amodei of Anthropic and Mark Zuckerberg of Meta have made bold claims about AI writing a large portion of software code — from 50% to 90% — within the next year or two. However, many software engineers, including Colton Voege and Simon Willison, remain skeptical, citing AI-generated code that is often flawed, requires extensive human review, and fails in complex or long-term tasks. Studies by METR and a Danish survey show mixed results, with one showing a 19% performance drop and another indicating only modest time savings. AI is most effective for quick prototyping or repetitive tasks, not for high-level problem-solving. Companies like Amazon and Meta have pushed aggressive AI adoption, sometimes leading to poor implementation, employee pressure, and even firings for non-compliance. Despite AI's growing role, engineers stress that human oversight, judgment, and creativity remain essential. The article highlights a growing concern that AI may displace junior software engineers and create unsustainable workloads, especially when used without proper guidance or justification.
title: Tech CEOs Say the Era of 'Code by AI' Is Here. Some Software Engineers Are Skeptical
